awd_titl_txt: An Open Science Platform for the Neurobiology of Language Community
awd_abstract_narration:
The advent of non-invasive brain imaging at high spatial and temporal resolution in awake, behaving human beings has had a profound impact on the study of language in the  brain. It is now the ten-year anniversary of the first international conference on the Neurobiology of Language, a field that has grown substantially since then and continues to blossom. Studying the neurobiology of language requires highly specialized skills (e.g., brain imaging) and broad multidisciplinary knowledge (e.g., psychology, linguistics, neuroscience). In order to promote scientific inquiry of the highest quality, it is vital to promote dialogue and interaction among the relevant disciplines.  This project explores how to facilitate this interaction.
 
The "neurobiology of language" is the biological implementation for representations and processes involved in the  production and understanding of speech,  sign, and language in context. Previously, brain structures and functions for language could only be  inferred from studying humans with brain injury. By monitoring the anatomical encodings and physiological dynamics of language processing  in awake, behaving human beings, researchers can now study human language at a biological precision previously possible only in  animal models (of functions other than language). Concomitant with these new approaches has been a  dramatic increase in the number of investigators dedicating their effort to understanding the biological  basis of language. The growth in the number of investigators and the use of expanded techniques and theoretical perspectives have driven the need for enhanced transparency, integrity, and robust and rapid research dissemination.  The PIs will explore these topics while developing systems and operations for open science, facilitating reproducibility and replicability of research, and dissemination of new findings.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The first conference on the neurobiology of language was convened in Chicago about fifteen years ago as a satellite symposium of the Society for Neuroscience, organized by Steven Small and Pascale Tremblay of The University of Chicago. The meeting was enormously successful and led to the subsequent formation of the Society for the Neurobiology of Language (SNL), which has met annually in venues around the world. The new field focuses on the study of the biology of the brain and its functioning for human verbal communication. Although this is not a new endeavor, the emphasis on physiology of the brain has only been possible in the modern era of brain imaging and electric/magnetic physiology.

After about ten years of successful conferences, Steven Small of the University of California, Irvine, and Kate Watkins of Oxford University founded a new journal for this field with the non-profit academic publisher MIT Press and with co-sponsorship by the Society (SNL). The new journal, Neurobiology of Language (NoL), aimed to champion high impact research, open science, low publication fees, gender balance, double anonymized reviewing, and other modern publication features. Many of the premier scientists in the world who study the neurobiology of language joined in as senior editors.

The journal has proved to be extremely successful, with many impactful articles published, and increasing recognition. After several years, NoL was awarded an impact factor -- critical to recognition and to obtaining top articles -- and many in the field took notice. This year, the second impact factor for the journal (3.6) puts it among the most impactful journals in the world in the neurobiology of cognition, and certainly the top journal in language neuroscience.

The journal launch was aided fundamentally by this award from the National Science Foundation (NSF), without which NoL would not be in its current position of prominence. Permitting the journal to keep low publication rates, to accept only the very best articles, and to maintain an upward trajectory, this grant was instrumental to creating the journal and enhancing this new field of scientific inquiry.

The founders, editors, and authors are grateful for the support of the NSF and the American taxpayers for giving us the opportunity to develop this new branch of science, which can have major impact on improving the lives of individuals with brain diseases that affect language, including stroke, Alzheimer Disease and other dementias, schizophrenia, and a host of other brain diseases and injuries.
